intro: Clarkia pulchella var. marginata, commonly known as the Sierra clarkia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the evening primrose family (Onagraceae) and is characterized by its showy, pink to red flowers with yellow centers. The plant typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as meadows and rocky slopes. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while the stems are upright and often branched. It produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain numerous seeds, aiding in its propagation in suitable environments.
